bestBHT.bht: The soldiers, in their abusive mockery, insulted the Jews by proclaiming Jesus as the King of the Jews. They not only spit on Him, but also struck His head with a reed and repeatedly slapped Him. Their actions were a deliberate display of disrespect, aimed at undermining Jesus' authority. This serves as a reminder of the rejection Jesus faced as King, as some rejected Him outright while others claimed His kingship only to disobey Him. May we humbly submit to Jesus as our true King and follow His commands faithfully.

Henry Alford: In the address, Hail, King of the Jews, they were insulting the Jews, as much as mocking Christ. See notes on Matt. vv. 27–30;—and on the purple robe, Mark, ver. 17.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: And said, Hail, King of the Jews!—doing Him derisive homage, in the form used on approaching the emperors.
And they spit upon Him, and took the reed and smote Him on the head" ( :-).
The best comment on these affecting details is to cover the face.
Marvin Vincent: The imperfect denotes the successive acts of homage of the soldiers as they came up one after the other.
They smote Him with their hands [εδιδουν αυτω ραπισματα] . Literally, kept giving Him blows with their hands.
Archibald T. Robertson: They kept coming and saying, 'Hail, the king!' in derision and mock reverence."
They kept on giving him slaps with their hands.
See on John 18:22 for this use of ραπισμα.
John Gill: They came and prostrated themselves before him; bowed the knee unto him, and addressed him in a mock way, as if he was an earthly monarch just come to his crown.
Thus mocking at his kingly office, and despising him under that character, as many do now: some will not have him to reign over them, but reject him as King.
And others, though in words they own him to be King, yet disregard his commands, and act no better part than these scoffing soldiers did.

bhtAttempts.bht: In John 19:3, the soldiers insulted the Jews by addressing Jesus as the King of the Jews and mockingly paying homage to Him. They spat on Him, struck Him with a reed on the head, and repeatedly slapped Him. It is heartbreaking to see the cruel treatment Jesus endured. The soldiers' actions were not only physically abusive but also a deliberate mockery of Jesus' kingly authority. These soldiers, like others today, rejected Jesus as their King and disregarded His commands. May we reflect on the immense suffering He endured for our sake and submit ourselves to His loving rule.

In this verse, the soldiers not only insulted the Jews by mocking Jesus as the King of the Jews but also physically abused Him. They spat on Him, struck Him on the head with a reed, and repeatedly slapped Him. Their actions were a deliberate display of disrespect and disregard for Jesus' authority. The soldiers' behavior serves as a reminder of the rejection Jesus faced as the King, as some rejected Him outright while others paid Him lip service but failed to obey Him.

The soldiers, in their mockery, insulted the Jews by declaring Jesus as the King of the Jews. They demonstrated their derision by spitting on Him, striking Him with a reed, and repeatedly slapping Him. Their actions not only physically abused Jesus but also rejected His authority as the true King. This demonstrates the disrespect and disregard that some people, both then and now, show towards Jesus and His teachings. It serves as a reminder to fully submit to His rule and not merely pay lip service.

Mocking and insulting the Jews, the soldiers hailed Jesus with the derisive title King of the Jews. Through spitting, striking, and slapping, they subjected Him to physical abuse. Their actions were not just an assault on Jesus, but a deliberate mockery of His authority. This passage reveals the rejection Jesus faced as King, as some rejected Him outright while others claimed His kingship but refused to obey Him. It is a stark reminder to acknowledge Jesus as our true King and submit to His rightful rule.
